HOW TO LAUNCH AND INFLATE RAFTS
CEILING RAFT COMPARTMENT
1. To open ceiling raft com-
partment, pull this handle
down.
2. Raft may then be lifted off
compartment door and
launched out nearest door.
HAT RACK RAFTS
1. To remove cover pull
latch down.
2. Rotate
buckle (like door
knob) to release straps.
3. Grasp top strap to remove
raft.
4. Launch out nearest escape
exit.
25 MAN RAFT
HOW TO INFLATE RAFTS
When raft is thrown out door into
water it is retained by this tape to the
airplane.
To avoid inflating the raft inside the
airplane do not lift or drag the raft by
this tape.
To inflate raft lift this flap and pull
ring and cable all the way out.
INFLATED RAFT
Automatic life raft radio
beacon. Rescue units can
locate your raft hundreds
of miles away by means
of this radio.
A boarding ramp can be
extended by pulling this
RED tab.
Heaving line. Quickly
throw this lifeline to peo-
ple in the water who need
help to reach the raft.
SURVIVAL
COUPMENT
IN HERE
KNIFE
PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS CARD FROM AIRPLANE
millsfield:images_texts:
FOR YOUR SAFETY. Know how to move out of this
SUPER DC-8
airplane fast. There is fire-danger any time a landing is
other than normal—particularly when the airplane struc-
ture is damaged.
Below is a floor plan of the plane you are in. Familiarize yourself with the location of the exits.
Note particularly the exits nearest you. Study how they are opened and also the protective position
you should assume during an emergency landing. When leaving, move to the exits immediately.
Do not go back for coats, purses, or other personal items.
A WORD ABOUT YOUR SEAT BELT-Rough air (turbulence) at high altitudes, although
infrequent, can be severe. When the seat belt sign is lighted in-flight, please comply with the sign
to prevent possible injury. Seasoned air travelers usually leave their seat belts fastened all the
time and pull them up snug whenever the seat belt sign is lighted.
CA 318 3-67 PRINTED IN U.S.A. (3)

HOW TO USE THE OXYGEN MASK
Jet aircraft fly at high altitude and the cabin is pressurized for your comfort. If cabin
pressure ever was lost, you would be breathing high altitude "thin" air ... so it is
imperative that cigars and cigarettes be extinguished immediately and oxygen masks
be put on as shown below.
